title: 107_hr1623
content: The Act may be cited as the "Historically Women's Public Colleges or Universities Historic Building Restoration and Preservation Act". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Act defines "historically women's public college or university" as institutions created between 1836 and 1908 for women's industrial education, and "historic building or structure" as those listed on the National Register of Historic Places or designated as National Historic Landmarks. The term "historic building or structure" refers to buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places, designated as National Historic Landmarks, or located within historic districts. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Preservation and restoration grants are available for historic buildings and structures at historically women's public colleges or universities. Preservation and restoration grants are awarded to historically women's public colleges or universities for historic buildings and structures on their campuses. Grants are funded through appropriations for the National Historic Preservation Act for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Grants awarded under the National Historic Preservation Act for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 come with conditions. Grantees must agree to seek approval from the Secretary for any alterations to the property and allow public access for interpretive and educational purposes. Grantees must seek approval from the Secretary for alterations to the property and allow public access for interpretive and educational purposes. The Secretary may use funds for buildings or structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Secretary may allocate funds for a grant related to a historic building or structure only if the grantee agrees to provide 50% of the program costs from non-Federal sources. In-kind contributions are also accepted in addition to cash outlays. Funding provisions state that up to $16,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006 may be available for the program, with non-Federal sources providing 50% of the costs through cash or in-kind contributions. Funding provisions allocate $16,000,000 annually from 2002 to 2006 for grants under subsection (a), with $2,000,000 designated for Mississippi University for Women and Georgia College and State University in fiscal year 2002. $2,000,000 allocated annually from 2002 to 2006 for each of the following universities: Mississippi University for Women, Georgia College and State University, University of North Carolina, Winthrop University, University of Montevallo, and Texas Woman's University. In fiscal year 2002, less than $16,000,000 is available for the following universities: University of Montevallo in Alabama, Texas Woman's University in Texas, University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma in Oklahoma, and Wesleyan College in Georgia. If less than $16,000,000 is available for fiscal year 2002, the amount allocated to listed institutions will be reduced by the same amount. Funds for fiscal years 2003-2006 will be distributed to grantees named in paragraph (2)(A) according to specified provisions. The Secretary will distribute funds for fiscal years 2003-2006 to eligible grantees named in paragraph (2)(A) on a uniform basis. Regulations necessary to implement this Act will be promulgated by the Secretary.
